newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy's San Paolo bank announces privatising plan.
newsitem.headline: Italy's San Paolo bank announces privatising plan.

text.p: San Paolo, Italy's largest banking group, announced on Thursday it planned to offer a major stake on the stock market in a move which would turn the firm into an independent public company.

San Paolo Holding, which controls 65 percent of San Paolo bank, said in a statement it planned to offer a total 45 percent of Istituto San Paolo di Torino bank's capital through a private placement and a public sale offer (OPV).
"At the end of the project the bank will be a public company without controlling shareholders," it said.
San Paolo is controlled ultimately, like many Italian banks, by a charitable foundation, Compagnia di San Paolo, but its immediate majority shareholder is San Paolo Holding SpA.
The bank also said Italian academic and novelist Umberto Eco, author of best selling book "The Name of the Rose", had been appointed to the board of the foundation.

The banking group did not say when it expected the sell-off to be completed, noting it still had to obtain the necessary authorisation. But group chairman Gianni Zandano said last year the group was looking to privatise in 1997.
The project envisages a two-phase privatisation with around 20 percent being offered to strategic and institutional investors who would form a stable core of shareholders.
A further 25 percent would then be offered publically on the domestic and international markets.

San Paolo Holding is 100 percent controlled by the foundation and the project aims to reduce the Compagnia's stake in the bank to around 20-25 percent, with a plan also for limited voting rights on that remnant stake.

The move comes shortly ahead of an expected shake-up in Italy's overcrowded and underperforming banking sector, where many banks are controlled by charitable foundations which are themselves often controlled by local and national state bodies.
The cabinet of Prime Minister Romano Prodi earlier on Thursday approved a draft delegate law on restructuring the banking sector and the nonprofit-making foundations.
The draft law aims to encourage reorganisation and concentration in the sector where analysts say rationalisation is needed to match other European countries' banking industries.
